sections.heading: ABSTRACT
sections.text:
Amino acids have attracted considerable attention in drug development because they
play important roles in many physiological and pathological processes. In the past
several decades, various amino acid supplementations have been reported to have
potential therapeutic efficacy for the treatment of many disorders in clinical trials.
However, their effectiveness is controversially reported, which may be explained by poor
pharmacokinetic properties of such low-molecular-weight agents. Amino acid-based
self-assembled macromolecules could overcome the aforementioned drawbacks by
improving the pharmacokinetic profile and accumulation of specific molecules at target
sites to enhance the therapeutic effect. In this review, we have discussed the current
therapeutic applications of certain amino acids, and have introduced our approach of
using amino acid-based self-assembled nanostructures as novel therapeutic agents.
KEYWORDS: self-assembled drug, nano-drug, macromolecules, amino acid, peptide
therapy

sections.heading: 1. Amino acid therapies
sections.text:
Since the development of aspirin by acetylation of salicylic acid, drugs have been mainly developed by synthetic organic chemistry for over 100 years. 1 Most of these
drugs are low-molecular-weight (LMW) compounds; however, upon administration,
many LMW molecules exhibit a non-specific distribution throughout the body, leading
Jo ur
na l P
re -p
ro of
to undesired therapeutic efficacy and adverse effects towards normal organs. Amino
acid-based drugs have attracted great attention as promising therapeutic medications as
many diseases are driven by deficiency of a specific protein or amino acid. Amino acids
play many critical roles in the body as building blocks of functional proteins and
produce important secondary metabolism molecules to maintain the normal
physiological conditions. They also participate in cellular signaling pathways and gene expression, and exhibit antioxidant properties in redox homeostasis.2 Besides, LMW
amino acids are conventional therapeutic candidates that can be easily synthesized and
administered. Therefore, amino acid supplements have been widely used in the market
and in research to improve body metabolism and human health and numerous studies
have reported the therapeutic efficacy of amino acids in treatment of different diseases
in clinical trials (Table 1). For example, tryptophan and tyrosine have been utilized as
precursors of amino acid therapy in treatment of several diseases including brain
disorders as these amino acids are metabolized upon administration and generate
critical neurotransmitters, including serotonin and dopamine, for the brain. L-Arginine
is an important precursor in the synthesis of nitric oxide (NO), which is a signaling
gaseous molecule with vital functions in the immune and cardiovascular systems.
Numerous studies have demonstrated the effect of L-arginine in treatment of patients with hypertension and in animal models.3,4,5 Besides, L-arginine supplementation has
been studied for treatment of obesity through reduction of blood glucose levels and improvement of insulin sensitivity.6,7 L-Serine, a non-essential amino acid, has been
reported to have a wide range of applications in various diseases such as diabetes and neurodegenerative diseases.8,9 Moreover, branched-chain amino acids including valine,
leucine, and isoleucine have been investigated for treatment of patients with chronic
Jo ur
al P
re -p
ro of
liver diseases such as liver fibrosis, cirrhosis, and hepatocarcinoma.10,11 Administration
of leucine was also reported to stimulate the release of insulin in the treatment of type 2
diabetes by activating glutamine dehydrogenase and mitochondrial oxidative decarboxylation and improving -cell function in the pancreatic islets.12,13 Furthermore,
leucine-enriched amino acid supplementation was recently demonstrated to improve
muscle mass, strength, and physical function in older post-stroke patients with sarcopenia.14 Conversely, it is well-known that the metabolic disorders of amino acid
lead to cellular dysfunction and diseases such as phenylketonuria, tyrosinemia,
homocystinuria, and maple syrup urine disease. For example, decreased metabolism of
phenylalanine leads to its accumulation in the brain of patients with phenylketonuria,
leading to behavior problems and mental disorders. In several studies, the
administration of combined large neutral amino acids significantly suppressed the
plasma phenylalanine level and improved phenylketonuria-related symptoms by competing with phenylalanine at the blood-brain-barrier and intestinal mucosa.15,16,17 In
addition to the 20 natural amino acids, therapeutic applications of non-natural and non-proteinogenic amino acids have been recently investigated.18,19
The underlying mechanism of amino acid therapy is to maintain the balance
between amino acid metabolism and redox homeostasis, which is disturbed under
disease conditions. However, the treatment efficiency of amino acid therapy in certain
disorders is concluded with controversial results, and large-scale prospective studies are required for evaluating the therapeutic effectiveness of amino acid therapy.20,21 The
drawback of the application of amino acids includes poor bioavailability of the amino
acids due to their rapid metabolism and excretion. Upon administration, these amino
Jo ur
na l P
re -p
ro of
acids are rapidly metabolized and/or oxidized by physiological enzymes, leading to low
bioavailability and low activity in the target tissues. Besides, the administered amino
acids spread non-specifically throughout the body, reducing the desired drug
concentration in diseased tissue and leading to drug accumulation in unwanted normal
tissues, which may cause serious adverse effects. Although amino acids are essential
biomolecules that are required to be consumed daily, overdose of certain amino acids may cause unwanted side effects.22,23 To overcome the drawbacks of LMW amino
acid-based drugs, we have started development of polypeptide based self-assembled
drugs. Firstly, amino acids are water-soluble and have an LMW, which decreases their
bioavailability. Our idea is to increase the size of amino acids via the self-assembly
mechanism. Therefore, the development of stable self-assembling molecules with
specific targeting ability would be ideal for amino acid-based therapy.

sections.heading: 2. Amino acid-based self-assembled nanostructures as novel drugs
sections.text:
For several decades, poly(amino acid)s have been widely used as the drug and gene
delivery in pharmaceutical applications. For examples, poly(ethylene
glycol)-b-poly(glutamic acid) micelles incorporated cisplatin to improve the
Jo ur
na l P
re -p
ro of
accumulation of chemotherapeutic agents in the tumor tissue and to reduce its adverse
effect.24,25 Amino acid-based polycation as gene delivery systems such as poly(ornithine)
and poly(lysin) exhibited the high ability in silence gene expression and gene transfection
for the treatment of the central nervous system and cancer.26,27,28 Poly(amino acid)-based
hydrogel systems have also been developed to apply in tissue engineering and
regenerative medicine.29,30,31 The application of poly(amino acid)s as therapeutics has
been investigated. In recent clinical studies, however, the physical encapsulation of such
small molecular weight drugs in such polymeric micelles often leaks them out during the
circulation and were not show remarkable therapeutic effects. Besides, several kinds of
proteins such as antibodies and enzymes have recently been approved as drugs in place of
small molecule drugs.32,33 For example, immune checkpoint inhibitors such as Opdivo
(nivolumab) are effective in certain patients with cancer, and hence, such
biopharmaceuticals are being actively developed. 34,35 Glatiramer acetate, which is a
synthetic peptide composed of random sequences of four amino acids including alanine,
lysine, glutamic acid, tyrosine, has been approved for treatment of multiple sclerosis as
an immunomodulatory therapeutics, , although its mechanism is not clear.36,37 It may be
much interesting if our self-assembling drug-concept is introduced to this system. The
production process of protein pharmaceuticals is basically complicated, which increases
Jo ur
na l P
epr
oo f
the cost of the drugs.38 In the field of polymer science, it is easy to synthesize poly(amino
acid)s via ring-opening polymerization of -amino acid N-carboxyanhydride (NCA).39
The poly(amino acid)s are anticipated to enzymatically degrade and liberate monomeric
amino acid molecules in vivo.40,41 Therefore, synthetic poly(amino acid)s can be used as
a source of monomeric amino acids for therapeutic applications. Our idea is to employ
this polymerization technique to overcome the low bioavailability of monomeric amino
acids and to design effective amino acid-based drugs. The polymer which we designed
was a poly(amino acid)-based block copolymer, poly(ethylene glycol)-b-poly(amino
acid) (PEG-b-poly(amino acid)). The poly(amino acid) can form nanostructures in
physiological environments by self-assembling via non-covalent interactions including
hydrophobic interactions, electrostatic interactions, hydrogen bonds, π–π stacking, and
Van der Waal forces. 42 , 43 Therefore, the block copolymers form core-shell type
self-assemblies under suitable conditions because PEG is a water-soluble polymer, and
the poly(amino acid) segment can be modified with ionic or hydrophobic forces to form a
nano-supramolecular structure in aqueous media.43 Since poly(amino acid)s are mainly
composed of the bioavailable amino acid backbone linking with peptide linkage, the
safety of their use in vivo is anticipated. It has been widely reported that poly(amino
acid)s display high biocompatibility and biodegradability under physiological in vivo
Jo ur
na l P
re -p
ro of
conditions. For instance, amphiphilic poly(-glutamic acid)-graft-L-phenylalanine
copolymers were hydrolyzed and degraded under treatment with different enzymes such
as protease, cathepsin, and lipase, which are highly expressed in the body. 44 The
biodegradation of poly(aspartic acid), alanine containing poly(amino acid), and their
derivatives were also confirmed by trypsin, lysosomal enzymes, and elastase. 45 ,46
Therefore, versatile poly(amino acid)s and derivatives have been developed to apply in
many fields of medicine and biopharmaceutics, as described above. This bioavailability
of self-assembling nanostructures with biocompatible PEG periphery is significantly
increased compared to that of monomeric LMW compounds, which distribute
non-specifically in the body.47,48 The concept of this approach is that after accumulation
of the self-assembling nanostructures at the target site, amino acids can be liberated by
physiological or pathological enzymatic degradation and exert excellent
pharmacological effects (Figure 1). In the next section, we will introduce examples of
specific poly(amino acid)-based self-assembling drugs.

sections.heading: 3. Poly(amino acid)-based self-assembled nanostructures as
sections.text:
therapeutics
The nanoparticle-based drug delivery systems (DDS) have attracted considerable
attention worldwide in the past several decades as a new medical technology; these
systems can alter drug biodistribution and control drug release, resulting in a significant
therapeutic drug effect.49,50 However, recent clinical studies on DDS have shown that
they have not been very effective and many DDS have failed in clinical trials.51,52 The
Jo ur
na l P
re
-p
ro of
physical entrapment of drugs in a conventional nano-carrier can cause drug leakage
during blood circulation in vivo, which may induce non-specific distribution and
unwanted adverse effects.53,54 Our idea was to conjugate amino acids to polymers via
covalent bonds and make them to self-assemble. Therefore, we can avoid leakage of
LMW amino acids. In this review, we summarized our recent studies on development of
poly(amino acid) self-assembled nanomaterials for several therapeutic applications. 3.1. Poly(arginine) self-assembled nano-drug for therapeutic applications of nitric oxide (NO)
Nitric oxide (NO), an endogenously produced bioactive gas molecule, plays diverse
important functional roles in various physiological systems including the cardiovascular
system, immune system, and nervous system.55 Besides, NO is also a key factor in
various pathological processes. The effect of NO is strongly associated with its
concentration and distribution in specific tissues. For example, in cancer therapy, a low
concentration of NO promotes angiogenesis and tumor growth, while a high
concentration of NO can induce apoptosis of cancer cells as a potential anti-oncogenic
agent. 56 ,57 Since NO is a small gaseous molecule with low bioavailability, once
generated at the target site, it rapidly spreads non-specifically and metabolizes.58,59
Although versatile NO delivery systems have been developed to enable controlled
release of NO at the desired target sites for therapies, antibacterial applications, etc., it
Jo ur
na l P
re -p
ro of
is not easy to control a gaseous molecule by the conventional delivery
methodologies.60,61 L-Arginine is a biological precursor and enzymatically modulates
the production of NO in healthy and pathological conditions.62,63 If we can accumulate
L-arginine at the target site, where NO synthase is expressed at high levels, NO can be
effectively generated. As we discussed above, since LMW L-arginine displays a poor
pharmacokinetic profile that the plasma concentration declines rapidly after intravenous
injection, direct administration of L-arginine is not plausible.64 Therefore, we have
designed a poly(L-arginine) based self-assembling system for cancer therapy using
NO.65,66 Poly(ethylene glycol)-b-poly(L-arginine) (PEG-b-P(L-Arg)) block copolymers
were synthesized by ring-opening polymerization of L-Arg-NCA initiated with
amine-terminated PEG. Since P(L-Arg) is a polycation, it forms hydrophobic polyion
complex (PIC) with polyanions such as chondroitin sulfate (CS). When
PEG-b-P(L-Arg) is mixed with CS, a core–shell type self-assembling micelle is formed
(named NanoARG), the core of which is composed of the PIC of P(L-Arg) and CS with a
PEG tethered shell (Figure 2A). The strategy involves delivery of poly(L-arginine) to
tumor tissue by passive targeting of highly colloidally stable NanoARG via enhanced
permeation and retention (EPR) effect, 67 followed by the capture and enzymatic
hydrolysis of the internalized poly(L-arginine) by strong phagocytic macrophages,
Jo ur
na l P
re -p
ro of
resulting in release of monomeric arginine in the macrophages. Finally, inducible NO
synthase (iNOS), which is highly expressed in activated macrophages, catalyzes
monomeric arginine to generate NO (Figure 2A). If this system works well to generate
NO at required levels, NO-induced apoptosis would suppress tumor progression.
Figure 2: Development of Nitric oxide (NO) therapeutic using designed PEG-b-P(L-Arg) self-assembled PIC micelle (NanoARG) for cancer treatment. (A) The strategic scheme demonstrates that systemic administration of NanoARG leads to the generation of NO in the tumor by activated macrophages. After intravenous injection, NanoARG accumulates at the tumor site via the EPR effect, and internalizes into the macrophages, followed by the degradation to arginine monomer, which is converted to NO by inducible nitric oxide synthase (iNOS). (B) In vitro study shows generation of NO using PEG-b-P(L-Arg) polymers during treatment with trypsin and iNOS. Poly(D-agrinine) and poly(L-lysin with guanidino group) are used as negative controls. (C) In vivo anticancer efficacy in tumor-bearing mice treated with a different number of NanoARG injections at same dosage of arginine base (16 mg/kg) (1 injection: blue circle; 2 injections: green triangle; 3 injections: orange triangle; 4 injections: red diamond; untreated: black square). Reproduced with permission from references [66].
Jo

A two-step reaction is employed to obtain PEG-b-P(L-Arg) through synthesis of
PEG-b-poly(L-ornithine), followed by the guanidinylation with
N,N′-bis(tert-butoxycarbonyl)-1H-pyrazole-1-carboxamidine. After deprotection,
water-soluble PEG-b-P(L-Arg) is obtained. The polycation PEG-b-P(L-Arg) complexed
with polyanion CS self-assembles to form the highly stable NanoARG at a
charge-stoichiometric ratio against salt concentration and serum addition. Using trypsin
as a protease model, it is confirmed that hydrolysis of PEG-b-P(L-Arg) leads to the
liberation of monomeric arginine. NanoARG does not generate any NO in the presence of
commercial iNOS; NO is only generated upon the addition of a protease. The level of
NO production is the same as that of the mixture of free PEG plus arginine, suggesting
that in the presence of trypsin, poly(L-Arg) is completely hydrolyzed to monomeric
arginine through the cleavage of peptide linkage of the polymer backbone (Figure 2B). It
should be noted that the changes in chirality (D-Arg) and side chain structure (L- lysin
with guanidino group) did not induce the NO generation (Figure 2B). This result
indicates that only poly(L-Arg) causes the NO release under the enzymatic degradation,
which is mimic the activated conditions of macrophage at tumor tissue. Using the
tumor-bearing mice model to evaluate the anticancer effect of NanoARG, it is interesting
to notice that tumor progression is highly associated with the number of NanoARG
Jo ur
na l P
re -p
ro of
injections of the same dosage (Figure 2C). The tumor size increases significantly in mice
treated with single and double injections, while no change in tumor size is observed in
mice treated with three injections and significant suppression of tumor growth is
observed in mice treated with four injections of NanoARG as compared to the control
group. These results confirm that a low dose of NanoARG enhances tumor growth,
whereas a high dose suppresses it, suggesting that NO can have different effects on tumor
progression depending on its concentration.
As stated above, NanoARG demonstrates the dose-dependent effect of NO in the tumor
environment in vivo. This indicates that NanoARG can be utilized for treatment of other
diseases. Since a low level of NO induces angiogenesis, we applied NO in local
angiogenic therapy for cardiovascular disease such as myocardial infarction. The NO
molecule is well-known to play an important role in protecting and regulating
cardiovascular functions including vessel vasodilation and angiogenesis. 68 , 69 , 70
L-Arginine supplementation has been suggested to improve the cardiovascular
functions via generation of NO; however, clinical practices have reported controversial
results.71–73 Administration of L-arginine may not lead to accumulation of required
level of NO at the target sites due to non-specific distribution, rapid metabolism, and
clearance. Even though NO is generated at the target site, it is rapidly eliminated upon
Jo ur
na l P
re -p
ro of
reaction with reactive oxygen species (ROS).74 It is generally known that high levels of
ROS are generated in diseased tissues, including tissues affected in cardiovascular
diseases. 75 , 76 The high levels of ROS rapidly metabolize NO to form
peroxynitrite(ONOO–), which further induces nitrosative stress and tissue injury, and
reduces the bioavailability of NO.77,78 To improve the bioavailability of NO and
suppress ROS in local target sites, a new flower- like self-assembled micelle has been
designed based on the cationic A-B-A type triblock copolymers of L-arginine
(PArg-PEG-PArg) combined with cationic triblock copolymers containing nitroxide
radicals (PMNT-PEG-PMNT) both coupled with anionic poly(acrylic acid), donated as
NanogelARG (Figure 3A).79 The former copolymer (PArg-PEG-PArg) can generate NO
via enzymatic hydrolysis by activated macrophages in the diseased tissues. Besides,
PMNT-PEG-PMNT serves as an ROS scavenging polymer to improve NO
bioavailability.80,81 Interestingly, these flower- like self-assembled micelles can be used
as injectable hydrogel as the micelles are converted to hydrogel under elevated
temperature in physiological conditions. In contrast to local injection of the polymer
solution, which localizes in tissue in less than 2 days, the self-assembled PIC micelle
(NanogelARG) solution converts to hydrogel immediately after it is injected through an
intracardiac injection, and the hydrogel remains at the injected site for an extended period
Jo ur
na l P
re -p
ro of
of more than 10 days, indicating the gradual release of composed polymers and
prolonged generation of NO in the myocardium tissue. Angiogenesis and NO generation
have been evaluated and confirmed through subcutaneous injection of the self-assembled
NanogelARG in the mouse abdominal skin. Treatment with NanogelARG significantly
improves the cardiac functions and reduces the infarcted area in a myocardial infarction
mouse model after intracardiac injection. (Figure 3B). In a study, it was observed that
not PArg-PEG-PArg gel but a combination of PArg-PEG-PArg gel and ROS scavenging
polymer PMNT-PEG-PMNT enhanced the NO level and therapeutic efficacy in MI
model mice. When only PArg-PEG-PArg polymer was subcutaneously injected to mice,
enhanced NO and angiogenesis were not observed. On the contrary, combining with
ROS scavenging polymer siginificantly enhanced the NO generation and induced the
angiogenesis in mice.79 The results of that study suggest that regulation of ROS or redox
equilibrium is important to improve NO bioavailability and treatment efficacy of
NanogelARG.

are regularly released by different cells to catalyzed bioavailable arginine monomer to
NO. However, overproduced ROS at the diseased tissue rapidly counteracts NO to
reduced its bioavailability. The designed NanogelARG with ROS scavenging activity can sustainably control NO delivery to maintain the redox equilibrium in the infarcted tissues.
As a result, NanogelARG treatment significantly prevents the progression of MI and

3.2. Poly(dopamine) self-assembled nano-drug for neurodegenerative disorders
As described above, it has been revealed that self-assembled nano-drugs based on
poly(amino acid)s exert significant therapeutic effects that cannot be achieved with
LMW amino acids. This section introduces the preparation and evaluation of
self-assembling drugs based on amino acids other than L-arginine. Parkinson’s disease
(PD) primarily affects the motor system and is the second most common and
progressive neurodegenerative movement disorder, affecting 2-3% of the population ≥65 years of age.82 The incidence and mortality are estimated to increase as the global
population ages. In patients with PD, degradation of dopaminergic neurons results in
decrease in dopamine levels, leading to cognitive impairment and difficulties with
movement. Levodopa or 3,4-dihydroxyphenylalanine (L-DOPA) is non-protein
constituting amino acid and is an important precursor of dopamine, which plays an
important role as a neurotransmitter in many neurological processes in the brain.
L-DOPA therapy is still the mainstay treatment for PD despite the high risk of uncontrollable movements observed in dyskinesia.83 Furthermore, L-DOPA and other
therapeutics such as monoamine oxidase type B inhibitors and dopamine agonists
demonstrate a short half- life, necessitating frequent administrations at high dosages,
resulting in several undesirable side effects such as stomatitis, sleep disturbance, anxiety, depression, and dyskinesia.84,85 To improve the therapeutic effect of L-DOPA,
Jo ur
na l P
re -p
ro of
a polymer-based self-assembled nano-drug has been newly designed. The poly(ethylene
glycol)-block-poly(O,O’-diacetyl-L-DOPA) [PEG-b-P(L-DOPA(OAc)2)] is an
amphiphilic block copolymer that is used to form a polymer-based self-assembled nano-drug known as NanoDOPA (Figure 4A) for the treatment of neurotoxin- induced PD in a mouse model.86 It is hypothesized that the peptide bonds in the polymer backbone
and protected acetyl groups of PEG-b-P(L-DOPA(OAc)2) can be gradually cleaved by
physiological enzymes such as protease and esterase to slowly liberate L-DOPA into the
bloodstream, improving dopamine conversion in the brain (Figure 4B).
PEG-b-P(L-DOPA(OAc)2) is an amphiphilic block copolymer, which can form self-assembling micelles (NanoDOPA) in aqueous media with a particle size that is about several tens nm in diameter. Enzymatic degradation of NanoDOPA has been investigated and has shown that NanoDOPA gradually hydrolyzes under chymotrypsin treatment, but
not trypsin. It is well-known that chymotrypsin specifically hydrolyzes peptide bonds of
proteins when the side chain of the peptide bond is an aromatic group. These data
suggest that the polymer could gradually release the L-DOPA monomer in the body’s
physiological environment, allowing its further application for in vivo treatment. As
compared to free L-DOPA treatment, an in vivo pharmacokinetic study demonstrated that NanoDOPA remarkably increases the L-DOPA plasma level and area under curve
(AUC) value after it is administered intraperitoneally (Figure 4C). As a result, treatment with NanoDOPA significantly improves the symptoms of motor disorder and
PD in mice induced by 1-methyl-4-phenyl-1,2,3,6-tetrahydropyridine (MPTP), which is
a neurotoxin that damages the dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra of the brain (Figure 4D). Interestingly, treatment with NanoDOPA also remarkably suppresses the
L-DOPA-induced dyskinesia in mice (Figure 4D). It has been reported that no
Jo ur
na l P
re -p
ro of
noticeable toxicity was observed in mice following long-term treatment with NanoDOPA. These results indicate that self-assembled NanoDOPA is a potential therapeutic agent for
treatment of neurodegenerative diseases such as PD.
liver injury
This section introduces another example of the self-assembling poly(amino acid)s
nano-drug. Acute liver failure (ALF) is commonly diagnosed and is a sign of severe
Jo ur
n P
complications related to other liver diseases. In patients with ALF, dysfunction of
hepatocytes results in high blood ammonia or hyperammonemia, which further aggravates damage of liver cells.87 L-Ornithine serves as an important substrate for
ureagenesis. Therefore, many studies have reported that combination of L-ornithine and
L-aspartate has favorable effects in lowering ammonia concentrations in patients with ALF.88,89 However, a double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled study showed that
the infusion of this amino acid mixture did not lower the ammonia levels or improve survival in patients with ALF.90 These contradictory studies suggest the limitation of
the application of L-ornithine in treatment of ALF. This can be also explained by the
rapid metabolism and excretion of LMW amino acids. Generally, L-ornithine is
administered through an intravenous or oral administration route, and the level of
L-ornithine dramatically increases immediately after its administration. However, the
increased level of L-ornithine rapidly decreases, and hence, multiple administrations are required, which may lead to side effects and cause inconvenience to patients.91 To
improve the bioavailability of L-ornithine, we have recently developed a nano-sized self-assembling polyion complex, named NanoORN, using PEG-b-POrn as the polycation and CS as the polyanion (Figure 5A). 92 It should be noticed that
PEG-b-POrn exhibits significant toxicity to healthy cells due to the highly positive charge, which is a sharp contrast to the low toxicity of NanoORN, which is due to the confinement of POrn cations in the core of the NanoORN. After administration, NanoORN
is gradually internalized into the bloodstream and accumulates in the liver, which is
followed by its enzymatic hydrolysis in the liver to monomeric ornithine, which
effectively suppresses the ammonia levels and improves liver damage caused by ALF
(Figure 5B). The in vivo pharmacokinetic profile and therapeutic effect of
Jo ur
na l P
re -p
ro of
subcutaneously injected NanoORN in the acetaminophen (APAP)- induced acute liver
injury mouse model were investigated. Although the level of ornithine in the liver does not change much in the first one hour after injection of NanoORN, the amount of
ornithine in the liver gradually increases up to four hours after the injection, and this
elevated level is maintained even after 24 hours of the administration (Figure 5B),
which is a sharp contrast to the L-ornithine monomer treatment. The area under the curve (AUC) value of mice treated with NanoORN is significantly higher than that of the
monomeric L-ornithine-treated mice. This result suggests that the administered NanoORN is delivered to the liver and hydrolyzed gradually by hepatic enzymes,
resulting in liberation of monomeric L-ornithine in the liver (Figure 5B). As a result, compared to the L-ornithine monomer treatment, subcutaneously injected NanoORN
significantly improves the liver injury markers, ammonia level, and histology in the
APAP-induced ALF mice model. Surprisingly, the condition of the liver after therapeutic improvement by NanoORN treatment is almost restored to that observed in
healthy mice (Figure 5C and D). Based on these results, the self-assembling polypeptide NanoORN may be considered a potential therapeutic for the treatment of
ALF and hyperammonemia related liver injury, such as hepatic encephalopathy. Jo ur
na l P

Poly(amino acid)-based self-assembled nano-drugs have shown great potential in
medical therapeutic applications. Self-assembled nano-drugs can significantly improve
the stability and pharmacokinetic properties of LMW amino acids, resulting in
considerable pharmaceutical response compared to LMW amino acids. This review
described several potential applications of poly(amino acid)-based self-assembled
nano-drugs including L-arginine-based NO therapeutics in cancer and myocardial
infarction, L-ornithine therapeutics in acute liver injury, and L-DOPA in Parkinson’s
disease. Importantly, poly(amino acid)-based self-assembled nano-drugs exhibit facile
synthesis and design in addition to the high biocompatibility and biodegradability, low
immunogenicity, and toxicity. Further research is needed to deeply investigate the
metabolism, pharmacokinetics, and treatment efficacy of amino acid-based
self-assembled nano-drugs for further development and application of self-assembled
macromolecule-based therapeutics. This concept, viz., "molecular assembly drugs"
based on a variety of poly(amino acid)s, may be expanded to various amino acids. By
optimizing the molecular designs such as composition ratio, number of the repeating
units of amino acids, and hydrophobicity by the protective groups, it may be obtained to

much higher pharmacological effect, retaining low adverse effects of the drugs. We are
also designing several other drugs based on this concept of "molecular assembly drugs"
for other compounds such as short-chain fatty acids.

sections.heading: Highlights
sections.text:
- A landscape of amino acid therapeutics is overviewed. - The design of self-assembled poly(amino acid)s as therapeutics is
presented.
- Self-assembled poly(amino acid)s significantly improves the
pharmacokinetics profile of amino acid.
- The treatments of poly(arginine), poly(L-dopa), and poly(ornithine)
self-assembled nano-drugs are described on the animal models of cancer, myocardial infarction, Parkinson’s disease, and liver acute failure.
- Designing the molecular self-assembling drugs is a new concept of
therapeutic development.

metadata.abstractText: This is a PDF file of an article that has undergone enhancements after acceptance, such as the addition of a cover page and metadata, and formatting for readability, but it is not yet the definitive version of record. This version will undergo additional copyediting, typesetting and review before it is published in its final form, but we are providing this version to give early visibility of the article. Please note that, during the production process, errors may be discovered which could affect the content, and all legal disclaimers that apply to the journal pertain.
